text: >> I would like to take this opportunity
to officially welcome you to today's webinar, Leadership in Turbulent Times. Joining us today are Bob Sutton,
Huggy Rao, and Kaye Foster. Bob Sutton is a Professor of Management Science and
Engineering and Professor of Organizational Behavior at Stanford. He co-founded the Stanford Technology Ventures Program
and the Hasso Plattner Institute of Design, better known as the d.School. Bob received his PhD in organizational psychology from
the University of Michigan and has served as Stanford faculty since 1983.
He's a senior scientist at Gallup, and academic director of two executive education programs, customer-focused innovation and the Stanford innovation and entrepreneur certificate.
Huggy Rao is an Atholl McBean professor of Organizational Behavior and Human
Resources Graduate School of Business and Professor by courtesy of sociology at Stanford University.
His most recent book coauthored with Bob Sutton is Scaling Up Excellence, which is a Wall Street Journal bestseller and was
included in the best business books to read in 2014 by Financial Times, Inc Magazine, Amazon, Forbes,
Washington Post, and The Library Journal. His research has been published in numerous scientific journals and he has
served as the editor of Administrative Science Quarterly and has been a member of the editorial boards of American Journal of Sociology and
Organization Science in Academy of Management Review. The thing is that these guys,
I can go on and on about them. They have lots of acronyms behind their names, but I just think that they're really solid human beings,
which is why we're so excited. I'm so excited to turn this over to Bob and Huggy, and they're going to be introducing our guest star and someone we are very
pleased to have joining us today, Kaye Foster. Welcome.
>> Thank you Robyn. I'll start out and introduce Kaye,
we could spend the whole time introducing Kaye, but we'll get on with the conversation and I'll ask her
a question and then we'll get rolling and keep your questions coming in. We'd love to see them.
Kaye first of all, had a long and distinguished and actually complicated career,
as a senior executive, perhaps most famously, she was head of HR of Johnson & Johnson,
there was some downsizing needed, so she's been in that kind of crisis. Then when I first met her,
it seems like about seven or eight years ago I first met you at UK. Actually in lovely Sonoma County.
She was part of an amazing top management team at a pharmaceutical company called Onyx that as I recall,
you all grew it from $0.5 billion to $7 billion company in just a few years which ain't easy in pharma,
and then they sold it and Kaye become a board member and she's on all these boards.
I probably can't remember all of them. Well, she's on Sanford Health board, she's on Spelman College's board,
she's chair of something called Glide Memorial, which is an amazing operation,
she's also on a private company board, Agios, I'm probably mispronouncing that,
and she also works with Boston Consulting Group, advising CEOs and other senior executives.
For the first question, since she's at ground central with
all these senior executives in other companies and organizations dealing with COVID. So Kaye, what's the big advice that you're giving to those executives you're talking to?
What do you tell them to help get them and their organizations through these times? >> Yeah. Good morning guys and thanks Bob and Huggy.
These are two of my favorite people to work with because they're real people. That's what I really appreciate about them.
In terms of the work with CEOs and this is CEOs across all of the various platforms that I work with,
whether that's philanthropic, whether that is public or private company, and it's three things I've been telling them.
The first is really what I call this pause because we're in this moment where there is such an intensity around doing something,
making a statement, putting yourself out there. One of the things that I've really asked them to do,
the first thing to do is to pause, and in that pause, the way that I describe it to them,
we're in this moment of character not content, and so many companies have really made
their mark and are valued for their content, what they do. When I use Boston Consulting Group as an example.
We are a strategies firm. We're known for our depth of research our rigor, our analytics.
But like so many other companies we are in this moment that it's about our character, it's about who we are.
How do our values actually shape the decisions we're making and therefore in this pause,
how can we be intentional about how we plot a path forward? So the first thing is pause.
The second that, and quite frankly I've told leaders to consider this moment,
this pause, as a gift. If you think about this as a gift and a pause,
how would you actually best use that gift in service of your mission?
That's the first thing. I would say the second thing that I tell them, and Bob you and I and Huggy talked a little bit about this.
How do you focus on what's critical versus what's least
important because you will tend to do what's least important because that's right in front of you.
That's the easy stuff. How do you really get to what is critical and how do you then deploy and get after that?
Those are the two things I start telling people, start telling my leaders to really focus on. >> Let me do a follow up question and then Huggy you can jump in.
I love the two bits of advice. Do you have any ideas?
This idea where, of course you should focus on what's critical, not just other things that are distracting.
Are there any hints or patterns that you see with executives to get them away from the stuff that is
taking all their time but it doesn't matter to get to the more important stuff because that idea of dealing with the cognitive load in
their attention is one of the hardest things for any leader. So how do you get them in the right place?
>> Yeah, it's interesting and I'll give you some examples. I'll do that throughout because I think that's the way to make this come alive.
If I think about, and I use this example with them. If I think about 9/11,
I happened to be in New York. I was in New York in the city that morning for a postnatal visit.
I had a four week old baby and a two-year-old baby in New Jersey with my sister and I happened to be in the city for postnatal visit.
I was at the time, I was head of HR for Pfizer, for a region we call JAALA,
which was Japan, Asia, Africa, Middle East, and Latin America. Pretty broad swath of geographies,
but I was on maternity leave. To the point of what was critical, what was interesting about Pfizer,
we were right in the city on 42nd Street as this unfolded. What was interesting about Pfizer,
they had always said what really mattered most to them was their employees.
In this moment I saw an organization get really clear that the order of importance number 1 was,
first of all, finding out where their employees were. We had employees deployed all over the world on planes,
we had employees in different parts of the country, and the first order of business was,
"Lets locate all of our employees and make sure they're all safe." The second order of business was setting
up a communications command center so that as a company, and that was our headquarters, we could get information to help us
understand what was actually happening relative to our employees. Then the third interestingly enough,
then was business continuity. I think that may surprise people that the first thing they didn't think about was business continuity,
but it was consistent with the values of the organization. The values of the organization was our people.
Therefore you see it directly going towards living into those values. It's back to the point I made about this is a character moment.
What I say to them is, what are your values tell you as really matters in this moment.
I'll give you one other example. Spelman College. I sit on the board of Spelman College.
As you could imagine, in the middle of Atlanta navigating through one of the most challenging,
not just pandemics, but all of the social and racial unrest [OVERLAPPING] articulated to that. >> Just crazy.
>> Then an economic crisis for the college, as a historically black college and university.
Our priority has always been excellence in education in its broadest context.
It wasn't just the academy, but it was also the experience that these women,
many of them first-generation African-American women, or I should say black women of the diaspora.
That experience of being together on-campus and
really being able to have an experience that was all around confidence-building,
really making sure that we were building whole women, not just focused on the academy.
With that as our priority, we started down a path of really saying,
"How do we move to a virtual experience that delivers that same level of academic excellence in its entirety."
That led us initially to say, we would consider bringing first-year students
physically onto campus as the only individuals who would be on campus. What happened over time is,
our priority wasn't just or our critical issue wasn't just about the academy,
it was also to be balanced with safety, and as [OVERLAPPING] the weeks progressed,
it became clear that we need it. It wasn't that we were thinking about the academy in the absence of safety,
but safety became the most critical priority for these women, for our staff,
and for all of the people who would be caring for them because of the way in which the pandemic was unfolding in Atlanta.
I think that's the other learning I tell them, it's not that your straying from what matters,
but you've got to be adaptable and flexible, and be able to pivot where necessary.
Make a long story short, we've now pivoted and we just announced as Spelman that we will be
completely virtual for all attendees in the fall. That's a tough, I can tell,
you that is a very difficult decision to make as an academic institution.
We're so much of what we deliver, our value proposition is about that in-person experience.
>> That's tough. >> That's beautifully described. Thank you again for being here and for sharing your wisdom.
I'm still thinking about your wonderful point about making a pause or pausing.
The reason I'm fascinated by that is, most people when they think of crisis,
they think the thing you need to do is respond very fast and very quickly.
What I hear your advice' is, "Hey, don't go fast, pause, reflect."
I find that wonderfully counter-intuitive. Now, listening to you and particularly as you
talked about the rich example of Spelman College,
it seems to me that people try and simplify crises. Is that a sensible thing to do?
How would you provide ramps to people for them to understand,
"Hey, this crisis is a little more complex." You want to improve their understanding,
but not overwhelm their capacity. How do you reconcile capacity under one hand with what the organization ought to do?
Can you share with us some examples of that please? >> Yeah, it's interesting because your point about
the tendency to want to move fast is sense of urgency,
one point I'll make about that is I've talked in this moment with leaders about compassionate urgency.
I am not suggesting that you not act with urgency because we have made urgency equivalent to speed.
For me, you can absolutely act with compassionate urgency because it means you absolutely have a sense of urgency.
In that cause, you're really making sure, what is the right order to take those steps in and any system that you are leading,
are you bringing the appropriate level of care and attention to that system? I talk about compassionate urgency,
I am not asking people to not act with the appropriate sense of urgency. But urgency doesn't mean speed for me,
urgency is about deliberation, it's about this sense of compassion,
and it's about this sense of thoughtful, about how you move forward.
Again, I want to make sure that people don't hear that I'm not suggesting you don't move with urgency,
but that you absolutely move with urgency. Your second point about capacity,
I used the word capacity as opposed to capability and I'll tell you why. Because in this moment the tendency is,
let's just throw more people at the problem. If we just had more people,
if we just attacked it full on, and one of the things that I have been suggesting,
both within companies as well as on boards, is to focus on capacity.
I'll give you the example of boards and then I'll give you the example of organization. On boards, one of the things that
I and my colleagues have been doing is we have been working to increase the capacity of the organizations that we serve by bringing our own expertise.
We've said to those, for instance, the college presidents or to the CEOs,
use us as resources. We've been through crises before. We actually have networks and we can actually
supplement and increase your capacity without you having to feel like you have to take it on your own.
I think this is a really important moment for board members to really be leaning
in and helping increase the capacity of the organizations they're aligned with.
With respect to organizations, it's a little bit of turning the pyramid on its head.
Moving from this strong need and this sense of control because,
again, to your point, in the midst of all of this uncertainty, complexity, chaos, what you want to do as a leader,
you tend to want to control and to narrow the degrees of control.
What I've suggested is you really turn that pyramid on its head and move to a more distributed model of leadership,
and really use this as an opportunity in a remote setting. Where you are virtual,
how do you empower the individuals in your organization? Because a lot of the either Innovation,
solution, a lot of that is going to bubble up from within the organization. I see it real time.
Our millennial generation is a generation that understands connectivity,
communication in a virtual world better than anyone that I know.
It's like leaders, I've been with some leaders who have been wrestling with culture.
How do you create connection and how do you reinforce and continue to strengthen
culture and engagement in a remote or in a virtual environment?
What I've suggested to them is ask people who know how to do this. My daughter, for instance,
who has been home since March in a remote environment from college. She is more connected than ever to her friends and they've figured out a way.
They've found an entire apartment and leased it and figured.
They did everything virtually and I walked in one day and there were six of them having a conversation. They've distributed out the tasks that everybody has accountability for.
All of that was virtual. This is my point about,
not just talking distributed leadership, but really embracing it in this moment.
>> I really love what you are saying, Kaye about distributed leadership and this example of your daughter,
of course, is striking and indeed illuminating. I was wanting to ask you a question about two things that are in my mind now.
One is, what you said was character, the other is capacity, they're the two Cs.
The third C, of course, is crises if you will. Can you share with us why is it some companies have a character and
capacity level that gets them to respond to crises as threats and other companies say actually, "You know what?
The crisis is an opportunity." What is it about their character and their capacity that
allows them to see the opportunity side of the crisis? >> Yeah, this might sound like a pat answer,
but it's about leadership. That's the thing repeatedly I have seen.
If you ask me thematically what I've seen in this moment, it's all of the things that we learn in school that you guys teach in the academy.
It's real leadership. I make the distinction between leadership with a big L,
which is all the things we've learned, which is my title, which is the hierarchy and small L,
which is really understanding that the solutions don't come from a small concentrated group of individuals who are the experts.
That expertise, again, like leadership, is distributed across the organization.
I think this idea of even thinking about, to your point, thinking about charter and capacity as levers for unlocking innovation.
You get that from the ups of the organization, not just because the CEO had a brilliant spoke of genius.
I think that this moment is just such a moment for us to be thinking about who are we in terms of our leadership?
Are we truly distributed? If I am in this organization, do I really understand what leadership in this moment needs?
I'm going to connect it to diversity as well because we couldn't have this conversation without talking about diversity, equity, and inclusion.
>> Yesterday, I was talking with a client and making the point that,
the reason to have diverse points of view or diverse individuals is because
their lived experience creates with them a context that is different than the prevailing context.
For me when I think about diversity and inclusion, I'm not thinking about checking the boxes,
I'm really thinking that gives me access to insights,
to understandings, that I just don't have. If you wanted then convert that into a commercial opportunity,
absolutely, that's not where I start. I give you the example of Onyx, Bob, you talked about Onyx.
When I started to work with Dr. Tony Coles,
who was the CEO there, we had a conversation about diversity and he said diversity for him
was not about a scorecard that was solely focused on representation.
He said, here's the premise, we are trying to do something that is incredibly difficult,
there haven't been any novel therapies in this particular area in 30 years and therefore,
we need the brightest, most innovative, most creative thinkers to be able to help us solve this issue.
Unless UK believe that a completely homogeneous group of individuals reflect the brightest,
the best, and the most innovative thinkers on the planet, we have to have a diverse organization.
I will tell you with that fundamental premise for how to approach building an organization,
we ended up and it was one of the most diverse leadership teams I've ever been a part of and it was one of the most diverse organizations I've ever built.
It was because we started with the premise as opposed to starting with a set of metrics or outcomes that we wanted.
>> Just to reinforce Kaye's point. I remember seven or eight years ago, in Sonoma walking downstairs and I actually hadn't looked at pictures of the top team.
I've dealt with a lot of top teams, the ones I deal with honestly are 90 percent male usually and especially White male.
So I walked downstairs, black CEO, Kaye's black and half men, half women,
half more than the United States, half not, and then I talked to somebody,
the CFO, and he started talking about his husband. He was one of few white males I'm involved with.
You guys just did great in that company. So Kaye, there's a number of questions coming in
and there's something that I want to ask about, because at least for me,
this is a moment that right now this is what I'm hearing from the organizations and leaders I'm working with.
In fact, recently I had a conversation with somebody who I think used to work for you.
He described how his fast-growing company, so he's now on the top management team.
He wasn't on top management team in those days, they all are so stressed that he sent out an e-mail about
a presentation at midnight and he got back two long responses at midnight.
He said, he realized that something is wrong. What are you saying with all,
because it's a really tough time. Every leader I know is just beleaguered. What are you saying to them about how
they take care of themselves and take care of the people, for what seem like a short crisis but now seems to be a way of life? What are you saying?
>> A couple of things. I start by talking to them
about caring for yourself so you can care for others, the old adage. But with people who are incredibly motivated,
who are incredibly focused on getting things done, I asked them to approach care of self the same way and I use myself as an example.
I actually, have a very structured approach to caring for myself because I placed
that with the same value I do as the rigor that I bring to advising clients,
the rigor that I bring to anything I bring that same level of rigor. I have a series of practices that I actually use everything starting with,
I literally calendar, what time does my alarm go off? What time do I get up?
The first thing I do in the morning is really care for, instead of practices that I know are important to feeding me.
So there's prayer, there's meditation, there are some stretches, there's really getting my head ready for the day.
I have also in this moment and I learned it the hard way because when we first went to Zoom,
I would be on these 12-14 hours Zoom days, and I just said to myself,
"Who am I in that moment? How can I coach others or advise others when I was
living out of integrity with what I was telling others?" I took a step back and really said okay.
I open up my office between 7:30 and eight o'clock. Are there times when I'm going to have to do something that flexes maybe
because a European team or a team in Asia asks for an exception? Yes. But I'm really clear about how I structure my day.
I wear a device, I won't call the name because I'm not advertising for anybody,
but I wear a device that reminds me to get up and move because it's also important for us to move.
You see that I'm standing, I have a standing desk and I'm standing because that also is part of keeping my system whole.
Then in the evening, I actually literally close my office door between 5:30 and 6:00 and I turn off.
Again, my counsel to them is you've got to figure out what works for you,
but you can't for two reasons: number 1, your energy is not inexhaustible,
that just is not the case. Then the second is, it's the role model that you are setting for
the organization in the way that you are adapting. Then the last thing I'd tell them is,
it's about being in integrity. As a CEO, I have one of my CEOs who was talking about the fact that flexibility mattered,
it was really key for recognizing that people who had caregiver responsibilities,
and when I say caregiver responsibilities, that's not just children and maybe parents,
that's animals that you may have to care for. He would say, people who have
caregiver responsibilities it's really important to recognize that, be flexible, but he was still sending e-mails and
expecting responses at all hours of the night. My counsel to him was,
even if you feel compelled to write an e-mail, put it in a draft, send it the next morning.
That doesn't mean that because we are in a crisis, they aren't going to be times when you've got to be all on.
But I learned this lesson at Johnson & Johnson, we ended up acquiring a company,
called the Corporate Athlete. The principle was based on the fact that executives are just like athletes,
and if you look at how athletes stay ready, they do a couple of things.
One, is they focus on food as fuel, so there's a component around nutrition.
They focus on movement because even when they're not on the court or not in actually in-game settings,
they're still focusing on movement. Then the third is either some form of reflection that could be prayer,
that could be meditation, that could be chanting, but it's the recognition that that's how
top tier athletes care for themselves to ensure that they're always game ready.
That's what I'm telling my CEOs. The last thing I'll say is, I tell them you vote with your time and your money.
If you show me your calendar on your checkbook, I can tell you what you actually value.
Not what you say in value but what you act in value. >> Brilliant.
>> Brilliant. I love this, I've been watching the chat with Bob and there have been a number of questions and I thought
I'd bring up two of them that I'm sure our viewers would love to know,
particularly given your spread of global experience and the fact that you're involved in so many industries.
The question that's being asked is, is managing crises a one-size-fits-all approach?
Or you have to change from country to country? The question was in the developing world.
A related question is, and I think this was prompted perhaps by your Spelman discussion.
Do the ways in which you manage a crisis change from industry to industry?
Country to country, industry to industry, what are your views on that, Kaye?
>> Yeah. I think there are some core principles that are consistent across the board,
but they are the nuances that happened. Let's pick country at a country level.
I remember being, as I mentioned, I had part of my remit when I was head of HR for that broad geography,
part of my remit was Asia and one of the countries that we had a very profitable business in was Indonesia.
I spent a lot of time on the ground in Indonesia in the midst of fires and riots and turmoil,
and in many instances people would say that absolutely was a crisis,
and we again led with the same principles under 911. The first thing was the safety of our employees and again
the way in which you execute that at a local level may be different.
In the Pfizer in New York, we actually have the capability of understanding where our employees were,
even though we didn't have obviously the technology we have today, we had better access to understanding that.
Because, for people who were traveling for instance, we had a corporate travel office and they kept
track of all of our employees wherever they were, if they were on a plane or if they were in a country outside of their home country.
We had an easier way of doing that. In Indonesia, that very much more of a counting.
I remember actually being in the office when we sent everybody out in the parking lot, and we literally counted everybody.
Again, the premise is still the same, we start with protecting our employees.
The second was communication and you remember the example I gave in Pfizer in New York,
where we wanted to insure getting communication in through all the channels we could and
then getting that faculty to employees in Indonesia same premise that was just executed differently,
and then with respect to business continuity, it also was, how do we make sure that this disruption,
these riots that are happening around us, what do we need to do to protect our assets? It's the principles I would say are generally the same.
It's the execution of those principles, and then the last thing I would say with respect to crises is it's really important to be adaptable.
Because particular dynamic environments, you can even though you may have set the course,
you have to be willing and able to adapt because you're not always in control of the context in which you're operating.
>> Lovely. One quick follow-up from one of our viewers. The question on participant in our webinar,
works for a very traditional company, and the manager believes in control
and so the question this person is posing to one of us is, "Hey,
the leadership in my company loves to control things, but we at the bottom levels of the organization see enormous possibilities.
What do we need to do to persuade our leadership to listen to us?" I think is the question that's being posed.
>> I won't be facetious because if I were facetious, I would say call me, I probably have a job for you.
But [LAUGHTER] I will answer seriously.
Look, one of the unlocks that I've found in these moments is actually come up with a specific idea.
Let me give you an example. I was talking yesterday with a client and one of the employees was talking about even the way to think about a company,
it's an insurance company and there was this concept that they actually insure mobile phones,
for instance and one of the conversations we were having was about diversity and I said, "Here's an interesting idea.
If my phone as a black mother of black children.
My phone, the phone that might children have is a lifeline.
It isn't just about making calls it's because when they leave home, I know that that is a way that they can contact me if they're stopped by the authorities,
if the breakdown along the side of road whatever is the dynamic that's happening.
That phone is not just to make calls or to text, that phone is actually a lifeline and if you
insure to make sure that phones when they're broken there quickly repaired.
The insurance that you're providing is on part with life insurance. The only reason that you would know that for instance,
is because you have employees of color in your organization who can provide that dynamic too."
We have that conversation that came up from the bottom of the organization, not from the top.
I think the more you can be specific about the opportunity or the ID,
the better it will be because I do think they are and that's my point of alternating the pyramid on its head.
The amount of innovation and inside an idea is that I see
manifesting coming up through the organization for me at this point in time,
it's one of the things that's giving me a lot of optimism. Because we so often have bought into this hierarchical way of thinking about leadership,
it's why I made the distinction between big L and small l. Small l that we now have in an organization.
I don't know if you have 500 people in your organization. They're not five people that are on the hook for delivering great ideas.
You now have all of these minds and you've said to them, "We want to liberate you."
I know how hard it can be, particularly on the point around control. One of the CEOs I'm working with,
has really struggled with remote work,
with virtual because he is still a CEO that believes in fixed time.
I want to visit people, I want to check the parking lot, are people still in their car,
still in the parking lot at 5 O'clock in the afternoon. I'm really coaching him through how can you be in that,
first of all, inquire from yourself why you still are on control.
Because if control means that you don't trust the people you have,
maybe you should fire all the people you have. Again, I'm not trying to be facetious, but these are the questions that I ask them,
because I think what happen so often we don't get to the beliefs. I spend time with them asking them what is the underlying belief behind control?
What's your insight about like why control matters so much to you? It's unpacking that creates some access
for some of the folks and then I encourage them to do experiments. How small you do something,
it's not going to break the bank, it's not going to blow the company up and it may actually be an opportunity.
Bring a group of people together and tell them to share the best idea that they have.
In organizations that are not as open to that, experimentation might be a way of doing that.
>> I love that. Bob, I think we've lost your volume.
>> Sorry. Is it back? >> Yeah. >> Yeah. I think it's back. Yeah. Anyway, I just hit my mute button.
Just a comment, just a few months ago, we were in conversations with an organization that came to Stanford.
They wanted to be more innovative and they described themselves as an organization where everybody wear suits and ties or the female equivalent.
You had to be at your desk wearing a white shirt by the way for a man at 7:30 in the morning and you left at five.
I really wonder how they're dealing with COVID.
You're mistaking control for creativity. Okay. Here's a question and this is a hard question.
This question is, I work for an organization with a management team that is white nation.
When I brought up the fact that our team does not reflect the community we serve, I was told to focus on diversifying direct service staff.
What's your comment on that? >> Well. >> An Advice. >> Yeah. [LAUGHTER]
>> So no surprise to you, Bob. That is not the first time that I've heard [LAUGHTER] something like that.
That person might even be my client. [LAUGHTER]
>> So what did you tell your client? [LAUGHTER]
>> [LAUGHTER] I'm big on storytelling because I think storytelling using my story or my experience creates an opening and an access for connection.
Because so much of the inability for others to see themselves and others that distance so even that example you gave.
That management team, there's no way that that management team was able to see themselves in that individual.
The distance between whether that was structural distance or whether that was ideological distance.
But the distance between them and this individual, they couldn't even understand why that individual was asking [OVERLAPPING] that question.
My counsel to the person or at least I'll start with the person and I'll start with the management team, even though they've neither asks for,
nor may I [LAUGHTER] not appreciate my [inaudible] [LAUGHTER].
I think these are also moments where you've got to make some really tough decisions.
Do you want to stay in the game? Do you want to continue to come forward from a place of solutions?
I really urge people in this space of diversity, equity, and inclusion particularly,
to really come forward with solutions or with recommendations or suggestions,
because I think what happens is we point out the deficiency. We say the management team isn't diversity enough or company isn't diverse enough.
What I help some teams to do is get real about why does it matter so it could be that you've decided at some moral imperative.
Or you could say there are significant opportunities that we are missing as a team that we need to be focusing on.
I'll give you a couple of examples. Because one of the things I hear a lot of the time is, our company is not customer-focus.
is not customer-facing. Obviously, diversity matters because if you
have a growing demographic that is Asian and Black,
Latin Acts that you need to be able to access that you want to respond to or connect with,
then of course, you are going to see a closer way of diversity having an impact on your business.
I use the example of biotech, I used the example of pharmaceuticals. Why should pharmaceutical companies apart from just the point I
made earlier about innovation and about the perspective, and lived the experience actually around problem-solving?
That's well-documented. I go back to how pharmaceutical and biotech drugs get developed.
We have clinical trials. Clinical trials historically have been populated with a phenotype that is not diverse.
One of the things I have argued and I continue to push for is
